scenarioDescription:
The K2-290 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-290 is a star with 1.19 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.51 times its radius. It is located 890.11 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 4 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

K2-290 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-290 system


K2-290 b

K2-290 b was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2019-04, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-290 b is 10.907 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-290 b is 3.060 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-290 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


K2-290 c

K2-290 c was discovered by the K2 observatory, in 2019-04, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.30 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-290 c is 246.132 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-290 c is 11.276 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, K2-290 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-290, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the K2.
name: K2-290 - System With 2 Exoplanets
